items.text: My self-esteem rises and falls depending on how others respond to me.
items.rationale: Directly captures the dependency of self-worth on external validation, the core of contingent self-esteem.

items.text: When someone criticizes me, I feel like my entire sense of self crumbles.
items.rationale: Reflects the fragility of self-esteem and its vulnerability to external negative feedback.

items.text: I need other people to recognize my accomplishments before I can feel good about them.
items.rationale: Self-worth is contingent on external acknowledgment rather than internal satisfaction.

items.text: A single negative comment can ruin my entire day and make me question my worth.
items.rationale: Demonstrates the disproportionate impact of criticism on self-evaluation.

items.text: I feel worthless when I don't receive the admiration I expect from others.
items.rationale: Self-worth is directly tied to receiving admiration, a hallmark of contingent self-esteem.

items.text: My confidence depends almost entirely on how I think others perceive me.
items.rationale: Explicitly links confidence to perceived social evaluation.

items.text: When I fail at something, I don't just feel disappointed—I feel like a fundamentally flawed person.
items.rationale: Performance outcomes are equated with global self-worth, reflecting contingent self-esteem.

items.text: I can go from feeling on top of the world to feeling completely inadequate based on one interaction.
items.rationale: Captures the volatility and reactivity of self-esteem to social encounters.

items.text: If people knew how much their opinions affect how I feel about myself, they'd be surprised.
items.rationale: Acknowledges a hidden dependency on others' opinions for self-evaluation.

items.text: I constantly compare myself to others and feel terrible when I come up short.
items.rationale: Social comparison driving negative self-evaluation is central to contingent self-esteem.

items.text: When someone I respect seems unimpressed by me, I feel deeply ashamed.
items.rationale: Shame triggered by perceived lack of approval from valued others reflects contingent self-worth.

items.text: I feel like I'm only as good as my last achievement.
items.rationale: Self-worth is contingent on continuous performance and accomplishment.

items.text: Sometimes I feel great about myself, but it never lasts because I always need more reassurance.
items.rationale: Captures the instability of self-esteem and need for reassurance, though the reassurance-seeking could also relate to Hiding the Self.

items.text: I feel empty inside when I'm not getting attention or praise from others.
items.rationale: The emptiness tied to lack of external validation is core to contingent self-esteem, but the emptiness could also relate to grandiose fantasy as compensatory.

items.text: When people don't give me the recognition I deserve, I start to feel angry and worthless at the same time.
items.rationale: The worthlessness maps to contingent self-esteem, but the anger at not receiving deserved recognition overlaps with Entitlement Rage.

items.text: Most people are not worth my time or energy.
items.rationale: Directly expresses dismissal and devaluation of others as unworthy.

items.text: When someone disappoints me, I quickly lose all respect for them.
items.rationale: Rapid, total withdrawal of respect upon disappointment is characteristic of devaluing.

items.text: I often find myself thinking that the people around me are incompetent.
items.rationale: Chronic perception of others as incompetent reflects a devaluing cognitive style.

items.text: People I once admired usually end up being a huge letdown.
items.rationale: The idealization-devaluation cycle, with emphasis on the devaluation outcome, is central to this factor.

items.text: I tend to look down on people who can't keep up with me intellectually.
items.rationale: Contempt for perceived intellectual inferiors is a clear expression of devaluing others.

items.text: When I realize someone isn't as special as I thought, I lose interest in them completely.
items.rationale: Abrupt loss of interest upon disillusionment reflects the devaluing process.

items.text: I secretly think most people are mediocre and have little to offer.
items.rationale: A pervasive, privately held contempt for others' worth is core to devaluing.

items.text: It's hard for me to maintain respect for people once I see their weaknesses.
items.rationale: Inability to integrate others' flaws with their strengths leads to wholesale devaluation.

items.text: I've cut people out of my life because they turned out to be beneath me.
items.rationale: Behavioral consequence of devaluing—discarding relationships based on perceived inferiority.

items.text: Other people's achievements rarely impress me because I can usually see their limitations.
items.rationale: Minimizing others' accomplishments by focusing on flaws is a devaluing strategy.

items.text: I find it hard to genuinely admire anyone for very long.
items.rationale: Chronic inability to sustain admiration reflects the devaluing pattern.

items.text: When friends or colleagues make mistakes, I find it hard not to see them as fundamentally flawed.
items.rationale: Globalizing specific errors into character judgments is a hallmark of devaluing.

items.text: I sometimes feel contempt for people who seem too ordinary or average.
items.rationale: Contempt for ordinariness is devaluing, though the 'sometimes' qualifier introduces some ambiguity.

items.text: I get frustrated when I have to work with people who don't meet my standards.
items.rationale: Frustration with others' perceived inadequacy maps to devaluing, but the frustration element could also relate to Entitlement Rage.

items.text: When people fail to live up to my expectations, I feel a surge of anger and want nothing to do with them.
items.rationale: The dismissal maps to devaluing, but the anger surge at unmet expectations overlaps significantly with Entitlement Rage.

items.text: I become furious when people don't treat me with the respect I deserve.
items.rationale: Rage triggered by perceived disrespect and unmet entitlement expectations is the core of this factor.

items.text: When things don't go my way, I feel an intense anger that is hard to control.
items.rationale: Disproportionate anger at thwarted expectations reflects narcissistic entitlement rage.

items.text: I have lashed out at people who I felt were not giving me what I was owed.
items.rationale: Behavioral aggression driven by a sense of being owed something is classic entitlement rage.

items.text: It enrages me when someone less qualified gets an opportunity that should have been mine.
items.rationale: Rage at perceived injustice rooted in a sense of superiority and entitlement.

items.text: I feel like I have a right to special treatment, and I get angry when I don't receive it.
items.rationale: Explicitly combines entitlement beliefs with anger at their violation.

items.text: When I'm kept waiting or treated like everyone else, I feel a burning resentment.
items.rationale: Resentment at not receiving preferential treatment reflects entitlement rage.

items.text: I've said hurtful things to people in moments when I felt they weren't appreciating me enough.
items.rationale: Verbal aggression triggered by insufficient appreciation reflects entitlement-driven anger.

items.text: I sometimes feel so angry at being overlooked that I want to make the other person pay.
items.rationale: Vengeful anger at being overlooked is a direct expression of entitlement rage.

items.text: When someone challenges my authority or expertise, I feel an overwhelming urge to put them in their place.
items.rationale: Rage at challenges to perceived status and the desire to reassert dominance is core entitlement rage.

items.text: I get disproportionately angry when I feel slighted, even over small things.
items.rationale: Disproportionate anger at perceived slights is a hallmark of narcissistic entitlement rage.

items.text: People who cross me learn very quickly that there are consequences.
items.rationale: Punitive stance toward perceived transgressors reflects entitlement-based aggression.

items.text: I can hold a grudge for a very long time against someone who didn't give me what I deserved.
items.rationale: Persistent resentment rooted in unmet entitlement expectations is central to this factor.

items.text: I feel irritated when others don't acknowledge how much I contribute.
items.rationale: Irritation at lack of acknowledgment maps to entitlement rage, though the milder affect could also reflect contingent self-esteem.

items.text: When I don't get the recognition I expect, I withdraw and seethe internally.
items.rationale: Internal seething reflects entitlement rage, but the withdrawal component could also map to Hiding the Self.

items.text: I feel entitled to more than what I get, and it makes me want to take what's mine by any means necessary.
items.rationale: The entitlement and anger map to Entitlement Rage, but 'taking by any means necessary' overlaps with Exploitativeness.

items.text: I have no problem using other people to get what I want.
items.rationale: Direct endorsement of interpersonal exploitation for personal gain.

items.text: I can easily figure out what people want to hear and use that to my advantage.
items.rationale: Strategic manipulation of others through impression management for self-serving purposes.

items.text: I often charm people into doing things for me that they wouldn't normally do.
items.rationale: Using charm as a tool for interpersonal exploitation is a core feature.

items.text: I see relationships primarily in terms of what the other person can do for me.
items.rationale: Instrumental view of relationships is central to exploitative narcissism.

items.text: I've manipulated situations to make sure I come out on top, even if it meant someone else lost out.
items.rationale: Willingness to manipulate at others' expense is a direct expression of exploitativeness.

items.text: If I can get someone to do my work for me, I will, without feeling guilty about it.
items.rationale: Guilt-free exploitation of others' labor is a clear marker of this factor.

items.text: I'm good at getting people to feel sorry for me so they'll help me out.
items.rationale: Using sympathy as a manipulation tactic for personal benefit reflects exploitativeness.

items.text: I tend to befriend people who can advance my career or social standing.
items.rationale: Strategic relationship formation based on utility reflects an exploitative interpersonal orientation.

items.text: I've taken credit for other people's ideas when it served my interests.
items.rationale: Appropriating others' intellectual contributions for self-advancement is exploitative behavior.

items.text: People are tools to be used, and the smart ones know how to use them well.
items.rationale: An explicit, philosophically framed endorsement of interpersonal exploitation.

items.text: I know how to make people feel special so they'll be more willing to do what I need.
items.rationale: Calculated flattery as a manipulation strategy is a hallmark of exploitativeness.

items.text: I've pretended to care about someone's problems mainly because I needed something from them.
items.rationale: Feigning empathy for instrumental purposes is a clear exploitative behavior.

items.text: I sometimes stretch the truth or withhold information to get people to cooperate with me.
items.rationale: Deceptive tactics for gaining cooperation map to exploitativeness, though the hedging ('sometimes') introduces ambiguity.

items.text: I find it easy to influence people, and I don't always use that ability for their benefit.
items.rationale: Acknowledges self-serving use of influence, though the partial admission could be seen as less pathological.

items.text: I deserve special treatment, and I know exactly how to get people to give it to me.
items.rationale: The entitlement belief maps to Entitlement Rage, while the strategic manipulation maps to Exploitativeness.

items.text: I often imagine myself achieving extraordinary things that would make everyone admire me.
items.rationale: Fantasies of extraordinary achievement and universal admiration are the core of grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I spend a lot of time daydreaming about the fame and recognition I will one day receive.
items.rationale: Preoccupation with fantasies of future fame directly captures grandiose fantasy.

items.text: In my mind, I am destined for greatness that most people could never understand.
items.rationale: A sense of unique destiny and superiority expressed through fantasy is central to this factor.

items.text: I frequently picture myself in positions of great power and influence.
items.rationale: Recurrent fantasies of power and influence are a hallmark of grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I imagine scenarios where I save the day and everyone realizes how exceptional I am.
items.rationale: Heroic rescue fantasies tied to recognition of exceptionality are classic grandiose fantasies.

items.text: I sometimes get lost in elaborate fantasies about my ideal life where I am celebrated and revered.
items.rationale: Elaborate, absorbing fantasies of being celebrated reflect the immersive quality of grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I believe I have a special talent or gift that the world hasn't fully recognized yet.
items.rationale: Belief in unrecognized special abilities is a core grandiose fantasy theme.

items.text: I often think about how different my life would be if people truly understood my potential.
items.rationale: Fantasizing about unrealized potential and others' failure to see it is central to grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I daydream about giving a speech or performance that leaves everyone in awe.
items.rationale: Specific fantasies of awe-inspiring public performance are prototypical grandiose fantasies.

items.text: I envision a future where I am widely regarded as one of the most important people in my field.
items.rationale: Fantasies of professional eminence and widespread regard are core grandiose fantasy content.

items.text: When I'm alone, I often imagine myself living a life of luxury and prestige.
items.rationale: Private fantasies of luxury and prestige are characteristic of grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I have a vivid inner world where I accomplish things that seem impossible to ordinary people.
items.rationale: A rich fantasy life centered on superhuman accomplishments is a direct expression of grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I sometimes feel like I'm meant for something much bigger than my current circumstances.
items.rationale: A sense of being destined for more maps to grandiose fantasy, though it could also reflect general dissatisfaction or ambition.

items.text: I think about how much better things would be if I were in charge.
items.rationale: Fantasies of being in charge map to grandiose fantasy, but could also reflect entitlement beliefs.

items.text: I fantasize about achieving something so remarkable that everyone who ever doubted me would have to acknowledge my superiority.
items.rationale: The fantasy content is grandiose, but the vengeful quality of proving doubters wrong overlaps with Entitlement Rage.

items.text: I try hard not to let people see my flaws or vulnerabilities.
items.rationale: Active concealment of flaws and vulnerabilities is the defining feature of Hiding the Self.

items.text: I would be mortified if people knew how insecure I really am.
items.rationale: Fear of exposure of hidden insecurity is central to Hiding the Self.

items.text: I put on a confident front even when I'm falling apart inside.
items.rationale: Maintaining a false confident exterior to conceal inner distress is a core expression of this factor.

items.text: I avoid getting too close to people because they might discover the real me.
items.rationale: Interpersonal avoidance motivated by fear of authentic self being revealed is central to Hiding the Self.

items.text: I carefully control what I reveal about myself so that no one sees my weaknesses.
items.rationale: Strategic self-presentation to conceal weaknesses directly captures Hiding the Self.

items.text: There is a huge gap between who I appear to be and who I actually am inside.
items.rationale: Awareness of a discrepancy between public persona and private self is a hallmark of Hiding the Self.

items.text: I feel ashamed of my true feelings and go to great lengths to hide them.
items.rationale: Shame-driven concealment of authentic emotions is core to Hiding the Self.

items.text: I worry that if people really got to know me, they would be disappointed.
items.rationale: Fear that authentic self-disclosure would lead to others' disappointment drives self-concealment.

items.text: I keep my struggles to myself because showing vulnerability feels dangerous.
items.rationale: Perceiving vulnerability as dangerous and therefore concealing it is central to Hiding the Self.

items.text: I have become very skilled at hiding my true emotions from others.
items.rationale: Developed skill in emotional concealment reflects chronic engagement in Hiding the Self.

items.text: Even with close friends, I never fully let my guard down.
items.rationale: Persistent guardedness even in close relationships is a defining feature of Hiding the Self.

items.text: I dread the possibility that someone might see through my carefully constructed image.
items.rationale: Anxiety about the constructed self-image being penetrated is core to Hiding the Self.

items.text: I sometimes feel like an imposter who could be exposed at any moment.
items.rationale: Imposter feelings relate to Hiding the Self, though they could also reflect Contingent Self-Esteem.

items.text: I tend to withdraw from social situations when I'm not feeling confident enough to maintain my image.
items.rationale: Social withdrawal to protect self-image maps to Hiding the Self, but the confidence element could also relate to Contingent Self-Esteem.

items.text: I hide my insecurities by acting as though I'm better than everyone else.
items.rationale: The concealment of insecurity maps to Hiding the Self, but the compensatory superiority could map to Devaluing or Grandiose Fantasy.

items.text: I go out of my way to help others, and I feel unappreciated when they don't notice my sacrifices.
items.rationale: Self-sacrifice coupled with expectation of recognition is the core dynamic of this factor.

items.text: I often put other people's needs before my own, but I secretly resent it when they don't reciprocate.
items.rationale: Altruistic behavior with hidden resentment at lack of reciprocity captures the self-enhancing motive behind self-sacrifice.

items.text: I pride myself on being the person everyone turns to in a crisis.
items.rationale: Deriving narcissistic pride from being indispensable to others is central to this factor.

items.text: I sacrifice so much for others that it makes me feel like a better person than most.
items.rationale: Self-sacrifice used as a basis for moral superiority is a direct expression of self-sacrificing self-enhancement.

items.text: I need people to acknowledge how much I give up for them.
items.rationale: Explicit need for acknowledgment of sacrifices reflects the self-enhancing motive behind the altruism.

items.text: I feel morally superior to people who are more selfish than I am.
items.rationale: Using one's own selflessness as a basis for moral superiority over others is core to this factor.

items.text: I give and give to others, and then feel hurt and angry when they take me for granted.
items.rationale: The cycle of excessive giving followed by hurt at being taken for granted captures the self-sacrificing self-enhancement dynamic.

items.text: Helping others makes me feel important and needed in a way that nothing else does.
items.rationale: Deriving a sense of importance from helping others reveals the narcissistic function of the self-sacrifice.

items.text: I sometimes do generous things partly because I want people to see me as an exceptionally good person.
items.rationale: Generosity motivated by desire for a virtuous image is a clear expression of self-sacrificing self-enhancement.

items.text: I have a hard time saying no to people, but I keep a mental tally of everything I do for them.
items.rationale: Compulsive helping combined with covert scorekeeping reveals the self-enhancing motive behind the sacrifice.

items.text: I believe I am more caring and selfless than almost anyone I know.
items.rationale: Grandiose self-perception centered on selflessness is a hallmark of self-sacrificing self-enhancement.

items.text: When I help someone and they don't seem grateful enough, I feel deeply wounded.
items.rationale: Narcissistic injury from insufficient gratitude for one's sacrifices is central to this factor.

items.text: I sometimes wonder if I help people mainly because it makes me feel good about myself.
items.rationale: Self-reflective awareness of self-serving motives behind helping maps to this factor, though the insight could reduce pathological quality.

items.text: I feel let down when the people I've helped don't seem to value my contributions as much as they should.
items.rationale: Disappointment at undervalued contributions maps here, though the sense of being owed could also relate to Entitlement Rage.

items.text: I've done so much for others that when they don't appreciate it, I feel a rage I can barely contain.
items.rationale: The self-sacrifice and expectation of appreciation map to Self-Sacrificing Self-Enhancement, but the barely contained rage overlaps with Entitlement Rage.
